awd_titl_txt: RAPID: OOI-Industry Partnership to Install a Cabled 45 kHz ADCP at Axial Seamount Caldera
awd_abstract_narration:
The PI proposes to test a new acoustic Doppler current profiler (ADCP) which has the potential, for the first time, to provide real-time monitoring of currents throughout the entire ~1500 m of water column that overlies Axial caldera. If successful, this instrument will be of broad use to the community with important applications spanning quantification of rising methane-and biologically-rich plumes at sites of gas hydrates, to monitoring changes in currents along continental margins impacted by ocean acidification and anoxia events.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Axial Seamount, located ~500 km off the Oregon coast, is the most magmatically robust volcano on the ~500 km-long Juan de Fuca Ridge and it is one of the best-studied volcanoes along the global MOR spreading system with four decades of field programs documenting eruptions in 1998, 2011, and 2015. In coordination with a commercial vendor, a 45 kHz Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP) instrument was installed on the Ocean Observatories Initiative (OOI) Regional Cabled Array (RCA) in 2021. The instrument was mounted, upward looking, to the Central Caldera seafloor junction box frame at a water depth of 1523 meters (4997 feet) with the goal of measuring water velocity profiles through the entire water column. While the instrument was successfully deployed with real-time communications, operational testing revealed that electrical noise, likely coupled from the cabled infrastructure, degraded the data quality. 

Attempts to screen and average the 45 kHz ADCP data do not reveal oceanographic features seen in data collected by a nearby vessel-based ADCP during the 2022 OOI-RCA maintenance cruise. There remains an interference term omnipresent in both the narrowband and broadband velocity measurements. It is likely that the interfering term’s origin is in the observatory’s power supply, as interference was replicated on a second similar 45 kHz ADCP instrument powered by a test junction box in a laboratory setting. The interference term does change over time, likely due to changes in the power supply load.

Investigating and implementing power conditioning for cabled observatory instrumentation ports is recommended in order to minimize electrical noise which may affect sensitive instrumentation.


Last Modified: 07/24/2024
Modified by: Dana Manalang

Image
  • Pinnacle 45 kHz ADCP installed on the Central Caldera junction box at the summit of Axial Volcano; deployment live-streamed to on-shore collaborators via Interactive Oceans (interactiveoceans.washington.edu).
    UW/NSF-OOI/WHOI/V�21
    Creative Commons

    45 kHz ADCP
